awd_titl_txt: Applications of Oxoammonium Salts to Green Organic Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Supported by the Chemical Synthesis Program in the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Paul Floreancig at the University of Pittsburgh uses electrochemistry to the synthesize complex organic compounds.  Electrochemical reactions use electrical currents in place of traditional chemicals.  Chemical reagents often produce undesired by-products because they produce too much or too little energy to make (or break) specific chemical bonds; Because electrical currents can be precisely controlled at a given potential (voltage), electrochemical reactions can be tuned to provide just the right amount of energy needed for a desired transformation.  In this way, electrochemical reactions promise to reduce chemical waste when compared to traditional chemical reactions.  This research produces new environmentally benign synthetic methods using electrochemical techniques. The research team works with collaborators to combine organic reaction development with theory and electrochemical techniques.  The new method development illustrate the power of employing oxidation reactions in increasing molecular complexity. The research team has a strong commitment to pursuing green chemistry and lessons learned through this research are used as examples in undergraduate classes directed toward environmentally benign organic synthesis.   

This project uses electrochemical oxidations to advance the oxidative carbon-hydrogen bond cleavage processes that have been developed in the Floreancig group.  The study replaces quinone oxidants, which were originally used as stoichiometric reagents, with oxoammonium ions. The oxoammonium ions are more readily regenerated through anodic oxidation than their quinone counterparts and offer additional advantages, such as easier reactivity tuning and the potential for developing asymmetric variants for enantioselective synthesis. The first objective is to optimize the electrochemical regeneration of oxoammonium ions in oxidative cyclization reactions to allow for low catalyst loading by exploring the impact of oxidant strength, electrode material, and substrate oxidation potential. The second objective is to gain insight into the mechanistic nuances of oxidative carbon-hydrogen bond cleavage by oxoammonium ions through a combined experimental and theoretical approach that provides information on the importance of charge transfer and geometry of the transition states. The third objective is to develop new transformations that are possible with oxoammonium ions but not quinones, including cycloaddition reactions and kinetic resolutions. By disseminating the results through publication and seminars, the Floreancig group provides the scientific community with powerful new transformations, valuable mechanistic insights, and blueprints for interfacing electrochemistry with oxidative functionalization reactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Converting carbon-hydrogen bonds, which are uniquitous in organic molecules, to carbon–carbon bonds allows for the preparation of complex molecules for application in pharmaceuticals and materials in a very efficient manner. This proposal focused on several aspects of such conversions. One aspect involved identifying the proper agent for achieving a particular process. We saw that a "one size fits all" approach to this chemistry is not suitable, and that an agent that promotes this transofrmation for one molecular class might not be efficient for a different class. We devised a set of guidelines to match the reactive agent with the molecular class so that these processes can be conducted with maximal efficiency. Computational studies aided in our understanding of the underlying reasons for the differences in reactivity, and this work also led to the identification of new chemical reactions that could not previously be done.

One of these reactions allows us to form nitrogen-containing heterocycles, which are a class of compounds that are of particular interest in medicinal chemistry. Our approach creates chemical intermediates called acyliminium ions and related species, which are known to be extremely valuable for complex molecule synthesis but which also are difficult to form. We prepared several variations of acyliminium ions that could not be accessed through previously reported approaches. This expands the range of nitrogen-containing heterocycles that can be accessed through these important intermediates.

The conversion of carbon–hydrogen bonds to carbon–carbon bonds, while efficient with respect to the reactants, is not usually efficient with respect to the oxidant, which is the agent that initiates the process. This is because the each molecule of reactant consumes at least one molecule of oxidant in these reactions, and that creates waste. We showed that the quantity of waste could be reduced substantially by reconverting it to the oxidant. This was done by using an electrical current. Similar electrochemical reactions have been reported, but this process is unique in that the transformations are substantially more challenging than those that were previously studied. This shows a generality to our process that should be quite useful for future efforts in envoronmentally benign chemical synthesis.

We also applied our oxidative chemistry in the formation of cyclic molecules that only contain carbon. This was achieved through the development of cycloaddition reactions. These processes involve the coupling of two molecules through two bonds, forming a cyclic structure from two non-cyclic precursors. This process greatly facilitates complex molecule synthesis. Our approach starts with a compound that is inert toward cycloaddition chemistry, though when it is exposed to the same conditions that we developed for the above processes it becomes highly reactive toward cycloaddition chemistry. The subsequent cycloaddition leads to very complex materials from simple precursors. 

Thus, we demonstrated that we can develop new chemical reactions with our oxidative carbon–hydrogen bond cleavage chemistry that will prove to be useful for the construction of numerous molecular classes. Our studies led to a fundamental understanding of the behavior of various oxidants, leading to guidelines that will help future efforts in the design of new reactions. We also improved the process through minimizing the environmental impact throough the use of electrochemistry.


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Paul Floreancig
